Shell very flat, outer surface with broad, flat ribs which hardly project beyond outline. Shell shape very distinctive, the anterior end extended into a spout-like lobe, such that the shape resembles a pear. Outer surface almost always heavily eroded, encrusted with coralline algae and often marked by scars of juveniles that frequently live on the backs of larger individuals. Inner surface of shell white with blue tinges and with a U- shaped, blue-black muscle scar.

The characteristic habitat, in which dense populations and their gardens create a virtual monoculture on the extreme low shore, is also a very useful identification feature.

Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to southern border of KwaZulu-Natal.

A very distinctive species both in terms of its unusually flat and distinctively pear-shaped shell, but also its distribution pattern and gardening habits.

Dense populations can monopolize the extreme low intertidal zone of exposed rocky shores, which is termed the ‘cochlear zone’. Populations can achieve massive densities of up to 1700 individuals per square meter. Associated with the paint-like pink coralline algae Chaimberlainium spp. Larger individuals also maintain narrow gardens of fast-growing, fine red algae, which they defend and on which they feed. Juveniles start life on the backs of adults and initially feed on coralline algae, before establishing their own gardens (sometimes on the shells of larger individuals). When an adult dies it is quickly replaced by a juvenile, which moves down off an adjacent adult and occupies its territory, hence maintaining a consistent population density.

Growth is initially fairly rapid with shell length of about 25-40 mm being attained in the first five years of life (depending on site), but growth then slows to about 1 mm per year, suggesting that large individuals may attain ages of at least 15-25 years, far older that any other regional species of limpet.
Herbivorous, feeding on algae, initially coralline algae but later also those from their gardens, which they defend, weed and fertilise with their waste products.

Sexes are separate and the sex ratio varied in different sites from 50 to 97 females per 100 males. Spawning takes place once a year, gonads reaching peak maturity in May with spawning taking place in June at some sites and over a more protracted period from June to September in others. Fecundity is low compared to other limpet species at between 120 000 and 212 000 eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
Unlikely to be confused with other limpets due to the very distinctive flat, pear-shaped shell.
